title: Mike Tomlin Steps Down as Steelers Head Coach After 19 Seasons
snippets: Mike Tomlin has stepped down as Steelers coach, ending a 19-year run in Pittsburgh during which he never had a losing season.
Who could replace Tomlin, how does this impact Aaron Rodgers and the QB position and more questions.
A 19-season era has officially come to an end in Pittsburgh as Mike Tomlin steps away as the franchise's head coach.
Mike Tomlin - the longest-tenured head coach in major American professional sports - has stepped down from his job as coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers after yet another quick playoff exit.

PITTSBURGH — The Mike Tomlin era in Pittsburgh is over. The longest-tenured head coach in major American professional sports stepped down from his job leading the Steelers on Tuesday after yet another quick playoff exit. The announcement came a day after the end of his 19th season in Pittsburgh, where he was a relative unknown when he was hired to replace Bill Cowher in early 2007. “Obviously, I am extremely grateful to Mike for all the hard work, dedication and success we have shared over the last 19 years. It is hard for me to put into words the level of respect and appreciation I have for...
Tomlin's largely successful run in Pittsburgh has come to an end
The Steelers are in the rare position of searching for a new head coach.

Head coach Mike Tomlin is leaving the Pittsburgh Steelers after 19 seasons, the team confirmed on Tuesday. “He guided the franchise to our sixth Super Bowl championship and made the playoffs 13 times during his tenure, including winning the AFC North eight times in his career.” Tomlin leaves the Ste
Tomlin is stepping away from coaching, for now.
After 19 seasons as Steelers head coach, Tomlin informed the team that he is stepping away from coaching, the team announced on Tuesday.

Without more context about the reasons for this change or its potential impact on the team, it doesn't contribute much to the reader's understanding or decision-making.
summary: Mike Tomlin has stepped down as head coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers after 19 seasons, the team announced on Tuesday. Tomlin led the Steelers to a Super Bowl title, eight AFC North championships, and 13 playoff appearances, and never had a losing season during his tenure. The Steelers will now search for a new head coach.

Nolan Arenado is on the move. The Arizona Diamondbacks acquired the veteran third baseman from the St. Louis Cardinals , the teams announced on Tuesday. The Cardinals will receive pitching prospect Jack Martinez in return. Arenado waived his full no-trade clause to facilitate the swap, per ESPN’s Jeff Passan. St. Louis will also pay $31 million of the $42 million owed to Arenado, according to MLB.com’s Mark Feinsand. The Chargers also parted ways with offensive line coach Mike Devlin. Roman spent just two seasons with Los Angeles, joining the club alongside head coach Jim Harbaugh ahead of the 2024 campaign.
